thread.title: Why are the national parks so crowded?
thread.title_full: Why are the national parks so crowded?

author: Ellen Creager, Detroit Free Press
title: Why are the national parks so crowded?
text:
The popular Riverside Walk takes tourists to The Narrows, where canyon walls nearly touch, at Zion National Park, Utah. (Photo: Ellen Creager/Detroit Free Press)
3 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE More than 292 million visitors made 2014 the busiest year ever for America's national parks. This year, attendance is up another 4% through May, according to National Parks visitor data.
What's going on? A combination of cheaper gasoline, more retiring baby boomers with time on their hands and heavy state tourism advertising campaigns may get the credit.
The Utah Tourism Council has been running a TV promotion called "The Mighty Five." It encourages people to visit Zion and the four other national parks in the state: Arches, Capital Reef, Canyonlands and Bryce Canyon.
USA TODAY
Zion National Park: Crowded but still serene
It has worked, but maybe too well. About 340 miles northeast of Zion, Arches National Park in Moab actually had to shut down for several hours on Memorial Day weekend due to miles of traffic gridlock â€” first time ever.
To help control visitation, several national parks have raised entrance fees. Zion's went up $5, to $30 per vehicle on July 1.
